title: Granddad with terminal cancer being booted out of caravan park after 25 years
text:

A grandfather with terminal cancer says he won't be able to enjoy the time he has left as he's being booted out of his caravan park.

Stephen Johnson has had a holiday home at Kingfisher Caravan Park in Ingoldmells, Lincolnshire, for 25 years.

But the 63-year-old man is one of many owners there who will be affected by a new policy, Lincolnshire Echo says.

Annual licences at the site are being replaced with 15-year licences from December 31, this year.

And no caravans over 20 years old will be allowed on the site from December 2020.

"I was diagnosed with terminal liver and stomach cancer in March 2019 and given a year to live. I had a heart attack in June," Stephen, of Manchester, said.

"We've never rented it out, it's been for our use only, and there's a lot of memories for our family.

"I can do without the stress of it all right now."

Another caravan owner there, who didn't want to be named, told of her frustration earlier today.

Caravans that are 15-years-old or older must pass yearly inspections in order to stay on the site up to a maximum age of 20 years.

The owners of existing caravans that were built 20 or more years ago have been given a year's period of grace from this December.

So, if a holiday home passes a safety test or necessary repairs are done, the owner has another season in which to decide what to do with their caravan.

But Stephen continued: "My son Steven died five years ago at the aged of 32 and I just want to give his two young daughters some memories of holidays at the park.

"I can understand that if some caravans are tatty they should get rid of them but there's nothing wrong with the caravans.

"Two years ago they agreed the caravans were ok and people have spent thousands on improvements only to face having to take them off the site.

"We've had new flag stones, a veranda, decking, and carpets and now we're being told to move."

A public meeting has been called outside the site launderette at 10am on Friday, October 25.

Other owners have expressed their anger.

Jordan Hugill, 25, from Doncaster, South Yorkshire, said: "We are not just fighting to keep the caravans on here, we want proper contracts, guarantees and assurances.

"Some people this season have been sold caravans that are 18 or 19 year old who have had letters telling them to move them."

Christopher O'Connor, 34, from Leeds, West Yorkshire, set up a petition on Change.org

He said: "I took my caravan on in January and it has cost me £10,000 so far which I won't get back.

"Before I took it on I got confirmation from the park that there were no plans at all.

"I now get a letter saying that because it's over 20 years old there will be an inspection by the council.

"The kids are heartbroken because we're going to lose it."

Mr O'Connor, an air-conditioning engineer, said £10,000 is a lot of money to lose, especially as he is off work sick until February after a car crash.

Mike Marshall, 62, from Nuneaton, Warwickshire, has been trying to sell his caravan due to ill health but says he now has little chance of shifting it.

He said: "No-one's going to buy it with these rules coming in."

Julie Baker, 62, from Barnsley, said: "I've had a caravan there for 16 to 17 years.

"It's the only place the grandkids go for a holiday and I'm absolutely gutted for them.

"We are heartbroken that we will lose it."

Kingfisher Caravan Park was approached for comment.
description: Stephen Johnson is one of many owners at Kingfisher Caravan Park in Ingoldmells, Lincolnshire, who will fall foul of a new policy
